statement:
**Theorem.** If a sequence $f_1,\,f_2,\,\ldots$ of real functions,
continuous on the interval $[a,\,b]$, converges uniformly on this
interval to the limit function $f$, then $$\begin{aligned}
\int_a^b\!f(x)\,dx \;=\; \lim_{n\to\infty}\int_a^b\!f_n(x)\,dx.\end{aligned}$$

*Proof.* Let $\varepsilon > 0$. The uniform continuity implies the
existence of a positive integer $n_\varepsilon$ such that
$$|f_n(x)\!-\!f(x)| \;<\; \frac{\varepsilon}{b\!-\!a} \quad \forall x \in [a,\,b] \qquad \mbox{when}\;\; 
n \,>\, n_\varepsilon.$$ The function $f$ is continuous (see ) and thus
(see ) on the interval. Utilising the estimation theorem of integral, we
obtain
$$\left|\int_a^b\!f_n(x)\,dx\!-\!\int_a^b\!f(x)\,dx\right| \,=\, \left|\int_a^b\!(f_n(x)\!-\!f(x))\,dx\right| 
\,\leqq\, \int_a^b\!|f_n(x)\!-\!f(x)|\,dx \,<\, \frac{\varepsilon}{b\!-\!a}(b\!-\!a) \,=\, \varepsilon$$
as soon as $n > n_\varepsilon$. Consequently, (1) is true.\
**Remark 1.** The equation (1) may be written in the form
$$\begin{aligned}
\int_a^b\!\lim_{n\to\infty}f_n(x)\,dx \;=\; \lim_{n\to\infty}\int_a^b\!f_n(x)\,dx,\end{aligned}$$
i.e. under the assumptions of the theorem, the integration and the limit
process can be interchanged.\
**Remark 2.** Considering the partial sums of a series
$\sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n(x)$ with continuous terms and converging
uniformly on $[a,\,b]$, one gets from the theorem the result analogous
to (2): $$\begin{aligned}
\int_a^b\!\sum_{n=1}^\infty f_n(x)\,dx \;=\; \sum_{n=1}^\infty\int_a^b\!f_n(x)\,dx.\end{aligned}$$
